It's never been easier to be a celebrity than in the 21st century, and Hugh Laurie has made a name for himself in the world of entertainment. Born on November 15, 1954, in London, England, Laurie showed an early interest in acting. He studied English literature at Magdalene College, Cambridge, before moving to London to pursue an acting career.

Hugh Laurie made his television debut in 1977 as a presenter for "Wogan," a British chat show, and later appeared in several British television series such as "Shoestring" (1979-1980), "A Very Peculiar Practice" (1986-1988), and "Boon" (1981-1988). However, it was his role as Dr. Gregory House in the critically acclaimed medical drama series "House" (2004-2012) that brought him international fame and recognition.

"House" made Laurie a household name across the globe. In this show, he portrayed the character of a brilliant, albeit unconventional and acerbic, diagnostician, earning him three Golden Globe Awards, three Primetime Emmy Awards, and a BAFTA Award. The show's success also led to two spin-off series, "House" (2009-2012) and "House: Medical Division" (2012).

Beyond his work in "House," Laurie has starred in numerous other projects, including a series of voiceover work for Disney's "Gravity Falls" (2012-2016), a British drama "The Night Manager" (2016), and a film adaptation of the same name, as well as a biographical film about author Aldous Huxley titled "The Children of Men" (2020).

In addition to his work in entertainment, Laurie has also ventured into the world of comedy with his stand-up act and two comedy albums, "Are You Normal?" (2007) and "The Life and Crimes of Hugh Laurie" (2011).
